This species is found in the Red Sea, southwest and northern Indian Ocean, Yemen, South Africa, the Andaman and Nicobar Islands, southern India, the central…
This species is restricted to southern and eastern Portugal and western and central Spain, from 100-1,300 m asl.
This species is restricted to the Sierra Tramuntana of northern Mallorca, Balearic Islands, Spain, between 10-850 m asl.

This species occurs in three areas in Brazil: east Amazonia (Pará and Amazonas), the 'Gerais' of Maranhão, Piauí, Bahia, Tocantins, Goiás and Mato Grosso in central Brazil, and in the Pantanal of Mato Grosso.

description: A small, social otter of South and Southeast Asia, notable for its reduced claws and highly dexterous forepaws used to probe for crabs, snails, and other prey in mangroves and wetlands.
range: The Asiatic Small-clawed Otter has a large distribution range, extending from India in South Asia eastwards through Southeast Asia to Palawan (Philippines), Taiwan and Southern China
The Western Honey Bee is native to the whole of Europe (Ruttner 1988), with the exception of Iceland, the Faroe Islands, the Azores, and northern parts of Scandinavia.
Ara glaucogularis is known from the Llanos de Mojos in north Bolivia. It is found from west of Santa Ana eastwards across the upper río Mamoré, Beni, where the wild population was discovered in 1992.
Arborophila gingica is endemic to south-eastern China, having been recorded in Zhejiang, Fujian, Jiangxi, Guangxi and Guangdong.

The millipede species Archispirostreptus gigas is widely distributed across eastern Africa, where it was reported from South Africa, Mozambique, Tanzania, Zanzibar, Kenya and Somalia. It was reported from the Kruger…

Athene cunicularia is distributed throughout the Americas, occurring in Canada, U.S.A., Mexico, Guatemala, El Salvador, the Bahamas, Cuba, the Dominican Republic, Haiti, the Netherlands Antilles, Venezuela, Guyana,…

description: A wild pig from Sulawesi whose males grow spectacular upward-curving tusks that can pierce the snout; it forages in forest for fruits, leaves, and invertebrates and often wallows at mineral-rich sites.
range: Babyrousa celebensis is endemic to Indonesia, and, as defined here, occurs widely on Sulawesi, with the exception of the southwestern peninsula where the form bolabatuensis is known from subfossials (Hooijer 1950). It…

This species is restricted to a single area in Viet Nam, where is was recently rediscovered living after a long period without records (F. Naggs pers.

Brachypelma emilia is endemic to Mexico and occurs on the coastal plain west of the Sierra Madre Occidental, from southern Sonora State, in Sinaloa State, southwestern Nayarit State and inland to western Durango State…

Brachypelma smithi is endemic to Mexico and occurs along the Pacific coastal side of the Sierra Madre del Sur, east of the Balsas River Basin, to the Acapulco region in Guerrero State, being sympatric with B. verdezi…

Widespread species occurring across Europe to central Asia. European populations are predominately resident, however some are partially migratory travelling to southern Europe or north-west Africa in winter.

description: A small Amazonian primate that moves by agile leaps through dense understorey and feeds on fruit, insects, and fungi; unlike many callitrichids it typically produces a single infant.
range: Callimico goeldii occurs in the upper Amazon from the Rio Caquetá in Colombia, south through the Peruvian Amazon and the extreme western Amazon of Brazil into the Pando region of northern Bolivia (Hernández-Camacho and…

description: A domesticated two-humped camel adapted to cold, arid climates, used as a pack and riding animal across Central Asia; its thick coat and fat-storing humps help it endure temperature extremes.
A compact domestic goat breed valued for hardiness and milk production; its small size and browsing diet make it well suited to mixed farmland and smallholdings.

range: This species is found in Chagos (Veron et al. 2016), Malaysia (Ditlev et al.

description: A shy, forest-edge antelope of southeastern Africa that browses leaves and fallen fruit; its rich reddish coat provides camouflage in dense undergrowth.
range: The Natal Red Duiker formerly occurred widely in coastal and riverine forests and thickets, escarpments and montane forests from south-eastern Tanzania to north-eastern KwaZulu-Natal in South Africa (East 1999,…

description: A threatened West African mangabey with a pale nape and long tail, living in social troops in forests and woodland; it is an opportunistic forager eating fruit, seeds, and invertebrates.
A West African guenon with striking facial markings and a white throat ruff; it is an agile canopy-dweller that feeds mainly on fruit but also takes insects and young leaves.
A robust armadillo of southern South America with long guard hairs over its armour; it digs extensive burrows and eats a broad mix of insects, roots, and carrion.
A small, largely nocturnal hippo restricted to West African forests and swamps; it spends daylight hours hidden near water and feeds on leaves, ferns, and fallen fruit at night.
A slow-moving, nocturnal sloth of northern South American rainforests with two claws on each forelimb; it hangs from branches and feeds mainly on leaves, supplemented with fruit.
A black-and-white colobus subspecies from central Kenya, adapted to life high in the canopy; it specialises on leaves using a complex foregut fermentation system and often leaps between trees.
A nocturnal lemur famous for its elongated middle finger, used to tap wood and extract insect larvae; it also eats fruit and seeds, including gnawing into hard shells.
Large herbivorous mammal native to South and Southeast Asia.
A plains zebra subspecies of southern Africa with broad striping and pale shadow stripes; it grazes grasses in herds and relies on vigilance and speed to avoid predators.
A plains zebra subspecies from southern Africa with relatively reduced leg striping compared with some populations; it is a social grazer that moves seasonally to track fresh grass and water.
A small nocturnal primate of southern Africa that leaps between branches using powerful hind legs; it feeds on insects, gum, and fruit and navigates by large, mobile ears.
A widespread West and Central African bushbaby adapted to dry woodland; it is a nocturnal leaper that feeds on insects and tree gums and communicates with loud, species-typical calls.
A tall African browser with a prehensile tongue adapted for stripping leaves from acacia and other trees; its social groups are loose and fluid, and calves spend time in nursery groups.
A giraffe subspecies of northern Kenya and neighbouring regions, recognised by its crisp, net-like coat pattern; it browses high foliage and can travel long distances between water sources.
The largest living primate, found in Central African lowland forests; it lives in cohesive groups led by a silverback and feeds mostly on leaves, stems, and fruit when available.
A critically endangered bamboo lemur confined to the marshes around Madagascar’s Lake Alaotra; it feeds heavily on papyrus and grasses and depends on wetland habitat for survival.
A tiny mongoose of eastern and southern Africa that lives in cooperative family groups; it forages by day for insects and small vertebrates, using alarm calls and sentinels to reduce predation risk.
A dwarf mongoose form from eastern Africa, notable for tight-knit cooperative groups and vigilant sentry behaviour; it hunts insects and small prey in savanna and woodland during daylight.
A small mongoose native to South and Southeast Asia that hunts rodents, snakes, and insects; it has been introduced to many islands where it can strongly impact local wildlife.
A nearly hairless, subterranean rodent from East Africa with eusocial colonies and a single breeding queen; it tolerates low-oxygen burrows and feeds on underground tubers and roots.
A large, nocturnal jumping rat endemic to western Madagascar’s dry forests; it moves by kangaroo-like hops and is threatened by habitat loss and introduced predators.
A large African porcupine armed with long defensive quills; it forages at night on roots, bulbs, bark, and fallen fruit, often leaving distinctive gnaw marks and tracks.
A domesticated South American camelid derived from the guanaco, used historically as a pack animal; it grazes grasses and is well adapted to high-altitude environments.
A highly social lemur of Madagascar’s dry forests and scrub, known for its bold black-and-white tail and sunbathing posture; it feeds on fruit, leaves, and flowers and uses scent for communication.
A small, endangered tamarin from Brazil’s Atlantic Forest with a golden head and dark body; it forages for fruit and insects and relies on tree cavities for sleeping sites.
An endangered Atlantic Forest tamarin with a vivid orange coat and a mane-like ruff; it lives in family groups and feeds on fruit, nectar, and small animals gleaned from bark crevices.
A slender, nocturnal primate of India and Sri Lanka that moves slowly and silently through branches; it feeds on insects and plant exudates and has a strong grip for careful climbing.

range: The distribution of Macrochelys temminckii is centred in the south-central and southeastern United States within river systems draining into the Gulf of Mexico, from the Apalachicola River system in Florida and Georgia…

description: A tiny antelope of East African savannas and bushland that often lives in monogamous pairs; it browses leaves and shoots and uses a short, flexible snout to pick food.
range: Kirk’s Dik-dik occurs in two separate regions: East Africa, from southern Somalia to central Tanzania and in Southern Africa from northern Namibia and adjoining parts of south-western Angola (East 1999, Brotherton 2013).

Mauremys annamensis is endemic to central Viet Nam, where it occurs in a narrow strip of coastal lowlands between the South China Sea to the east and the Annamite Mountains to the west. Eastward extensions of mountains…

This species is found in the Red Sea, southwestern and northern Indian Ocean (Mondal et al. 2019), central Indo-Pacific, north and west and south Australia, Southeast Asia, Japan, East China Sea, eastern Australia, the…

description: A small nocturnal lemur from western Madagascar that feeds on fruit, insects, and gum; it can enter torpor to conserve energy during cool or food-scarce periods.
range: This species is distributed from about the Onilahy River along the entire western coast to the north as far as Ankarafantsika National Park. A disjunct population is also found in the southeast up to the littoral…

This species is distributed from the Red Sea, Gulf of Aden, southwestern and northern Indian Ocean, central Indo-Pacific, north, west and east Australia (Atkinson et al. 2008), Southeast Asia, Japan (Lien et al.

description: Europe’s smallest rodent, adapted to grasslands and reedbeds; it builds spherical nests woven from grasses and feeds on seeds, berries, and small invertebrates.
range: The harvest mouse has a large range in the Palaearctic and Indomalayan regions, where it occurs from northern Spain and Great Britain through Europe, eastern Fennoscandia, and Russia to northern Mongolia, China, the…

Very widely distributed, breeding from Australia to Spain and Morocco, with the northern extent of migratory breeders extending to northern Russia and Mongolia. Migratory over much of the Eurasian range, predominately…
This species is found in the central Indo-Pacific, Australia, and the oceanic west Pacific. It has also been confirmed from West Malaysia and the Spratly Islands (Huang et al.
This species is found in southeast Asia, the east coast of peninsular Malaysia (Akmal et al. 2019), Vietnam, South China Sea, Papua New Guinea, northeast Australia, Solomon Islands, and Fiji.
This species is found in the Red Sea (Wilson et al. 2017), the Gulf of Aden, the southwest and northern Indian Ocean, southeast India (Kumar et al.

This species is found in East Africa, Madagascar, the Seychelles, Mauritius, Chagos Archipelago, the Maldives, western India, Sri Lanka, Myanmar, Thailand, Southeast Asia, Vietnam, southern Japan, Papua New Guinea,…

This species is distributed from the Red Sea, the Gulf of Aden, the southwest and northern Indian Ocean (Venkataraman and Satyanarayana 2012), the Persian Gulf, the central Indo-Pacific, Australia, Southeast Asia,…
This species is distributed in the Philippines (Veron 2002), the central Indo-Pacific, Vietnam, Papua New Guinea and northern Great Barrier Reef (Veron et al. 2016).
This species is found in the central Indo-Pacific from the Philippines, Malaysia and Indonesia. It is very poorly known and might be more widely distributed.

description: A threatened Malagasy mongoose restricted to western Madagascar; it forages on the ground for insects and small vertebrates and shows distinctive striping along the back.
range: This species is endemic to the dry deciduous forests of the central and southern Menabe regions of western Madagascar from sea level to about 125 m asl. It is found between the Tsiribihina River in the north to south…

description: A small deer native to China and Taiwan with barking alarm calls and short antlers; it browses woodland edges and has expanded its range through introductions in parts of Europe.
range: This species in endemic to China including Taiwan Island. In mainland China, this species ranges from Guangdong and Guangxi up to Gansu and Shaanxi, covering the vast subtropical region of the Zhujiang (Pearl) and…

Found in southern Senegal and Gambia, and Guinea, eastward to northern Nigeria and northwestern Cameroon, with its range extending south to the coast in Ivory Coast, Ghana and Togo (but not in Sierra Leone, Liberia and…

description: A domesticated form of the European polecat kept as a companion animal and historically used for rabbit control; it is a curious, highly flexible carnivore with a strong prey drive.
A diurnal South American coati that forages in bands, using a long, mobile snout to probe leaf litter; it eats fruit, insects, and small vertebrates across forests and savannas.
range: Nasua nasua is broadly distributed in South America, ranging from Colombia and Venezuela in the north to Uruguay and northern Argentina in the south (Gompper and Decker 1998). The species is absent from the Llano…
The Australian Golden Orb Weaver is widely distributed in Indonesia and Australia, ranging from Java to the Cocos Island and Tasmania. In New Zealand, it occurs seasonally in the Auckland area.

Nesoenas mayeri survives in the Black River Gorges of south-west Mauritius and on Ile aux Aigrettes off the eastern coast. Although once common, it declined to just 10 wild individuals in 1990, and were it not for…

This species is endemic to the central Zagros Mountains of Iran with a circumscribed distribution area in the Lorestan and Khuzestan provinces, where it has an altitudinal range of 385-1,500 m asl. It had been known…

description: A critically endangered gibbon from northern Vietnam and Laos; it forms monogamous pairs, travels by brachiation through the canopy, and is known for loud, duetting calls.
range: This species occurs in northwestern Viet Nam, northern Lao PDR and southwestern China. In Viet Nam, it occurs west and south of the Black River; it has been extirpated from several areas from which it was previously…

description: A medium-sized wallaby from southeastern Australia and Tasmania; it grazes and browses at dawn and dusk and shelters in cover during the day.
range: This species is endemic to Australia where it ranges through the south-east of the country. It is present on Tasmania, King Island, and on the Furneaux Group.

description: A Tasmanian form of the red-necked wallaby, adapted to cooler climates and mixed woodland; it feeds on grasses and herbs and is most active in low light.
A small, nocturnal primate of Vietnam, Laos, and Cambodia that feeds on gum, nectar, and insects; it can enter torpor in cooler conditions and is threatened by trade and habitat loss.
range: This species is found in mainland Southeast Asia east of the Mekong River in Eastern Cambodia, in Viet Nam as far north as far north as the Hai Van Pass in Quang Nam Province, and historically south to the vicinity of…

description: A forest-dwelling relative of the giraffe endemic to the Democratic Republic of the Congo; it browses understory leaves and shoots and uses its zebra-like stripes for camouflage in dappled light.
range: Okapi distribution extends across parts of central, northern and eastern DR Congo. North and east of the Congo River, Okapi range from Maiko Forest north to the Ituri Forest, then west through the Rubi, Tele and Ebola…

The King Cobra is widely distributed in South and Southeast Asia, from Nepal (where it is found throughout the lowlands of the Therai region - Schleich and Kästle 2002) and India (from Uttarakhand in Western Himalayas…

This species is a native endemic of the islands of Java, Bali, and probably Madura, Indonesia, although it has been widely introduced, with feral populations now established in many parts of the world. It was formerly…

description: A rare lion subspecies restricted to India, with males typically showing a relatively shorter mane; it is a social apex predator that hunts deer and livestock-sized prey in dry forests and scrub.
Large cat from the Americas, known for powerful build and rosette spots.
range: The Jaguar is the largest cat of the Americas, and the only living representative of the genus Panthera in the New World (Nowell and Jackson 1996). Historically it ranged from the southwestern US (where there are still…

description: A critically endangered tiger subspecies endemic to Sumatra, adapted to dense forest; it is a solitary ambush hunter of deer and wild pigs and is threatened by habitat loss and poaching.

range: This species is endemic to the eastern and southeastern United States. Its range extends from southern New Jersey, Maryland, and Kentucky southward to southeastern Louisiana, southern Mississippi, southern Alabama, and…
This tropical species is not native to Europe. It was first reported in Europe from the Algarve, Portugal in 2012, and from Cyprus in 2021.

description: A hardy African pig of savannas and open woodlands, often seen kneeling to graze short grass; its facial warts and tusks aid in combat and defence, and it shelters in burrows.
A Neotropical monkey with strong sexual dimorphism, especially the pale-faced males; it feeds heavily on seeds and unripe fruit and lives in small territorial groups.
A small titi monkey of the western Amazon with a coppery coat; it forms pair-bonded family groups and communicates with loud dawn duets, feeding mainly on fruit and leaves.
A brightly coloured forest hog of West and Central Africa with a red coat and white facial markings; it roots for fruit, tubers, and invertebrates and is often active at night.
A large fruit bat endemic to Rodrigues, feeding on fruit and nectar and acting as an important pollinator and seed disperser; it roosts in trees in colonies and is conservation dependent.
A highly social squirrel monkey of the Amazon basin that travels in large troops; it forages rapidly for insects and fruit and is known for complex vocal communication.
A widespread langur of the Indian subcontinent adapted to leaf-eating; it lives in multi-male or one-male groups, with a specialised stomach to digest foliage.
A cooperative meerkat of southern African deserts and savannas, famous for sentinel behaviour; it digs burrows and feeds mainly on insects, scorpions, and small vertebrates.
A domestic pig breed known for its thick, curly coat and high fat deposition; it is an adaptable omnivore that roots and forages readily on mixed diets.
A small South American anteater that feeds on ants and termites using a long sticky tongue; it is semi-arboreal, with strong claws for tearing into nests and for defence.
A South American armadillo able to roll into a near-perfect ball using its hinged armour; it forages for insects and other invertebrates in dry forests and scrub.
A day-active tree shrew from Southeast Asia that resembles a small squirrel; it forages on the ground and in low vegetation for insects and fruit and maintains small territories.
A domestic alpaca fibre type characterised by a dense, crimped fleece that stands out from the body; it is a hardy high-altitude grazer descended from the vicuña lineage.
A domestic alpaca fibre type with long, silky locks that drape down the sides; it is kept primarily for fine fibre and thrives on high-altitude grazing in the Andes.
